Introduction

Vitamin D deficiency rickets is a preventable disease caused by decreased mineralization of growth plates and softening of bones during childhood.  Patients classically present with skeletal changes, including widening of the wrists and bowing of the extremities.

Pathogenesis



Most bones, including long bones and vertebral bodies, develop through endochondral ossification, a process that begins during embryonic development.  Endochondral ossification starts with mesenchymal cells differentiating into chondrocytes, forming a hyaline cartilage model for future bone.  This cartilage template is then gradually replaced by bone through a series of steps.  First, the cartilage matrix becomes mineralized by the deposition of calcium and phosphate into the osteoid (unmineralized bone matrix).  Mineralization allows blood vessels to invade, triggering osteoblasts to create new bone matrices, converting the tissue to bone.  Ossification begins in the central shaft of the bone (diaphysis) and advances toward the ends (epiphysis), where new cartilage continues to form.  Ongoing ossification at these growth plates enables the replacement of cartilage with bone, supporting continuous linear growth throughout childhood and adolescence.



Disruption of the mineralization process impairs vascular invasion and prevents osteoblasts from converting cartilage into bone.  Rickets is characterized by defective mineralization at the growth plates specifically.  Although mineralization is disrupted in this condition, cartilage continues to accumulate, expanding in a disorganized manner, which leads to widening of the growth plates and the adjacent metaphyses.  Sites of rapid bone proliferation (eg, long bones of the appendicular skeleton, skull, ribs) are particularly affected, resulting in the hallmark clinical findings.



The most common cause of rickets is vitamin D deficiency, which results in low serum calcium levels, compensatory increase in parathyroid hormone and alkaline phosphatase, and low serum phosphate levels (

figure 1
).  This decrease in available serum calcium and phosphate prevents adequate bone mineralization.  Risk factors for vitamin D deficiency rickets include insufficient sun exposure (eg, northern latitudes, atmospheric pollution, full-coverage clothing) and inadequate dietary intake of vitamin D (eg, exclusive breastfeeding without supplementation, lack of vitamin Dâ€“fortified foods).



Rickets can less commonly result from calcium or phosphorus deficiency, genetic factors, medications, or liver disease.

Clinical presentation



Rickets often presents at sites of rapid bone proliferation in children age 6 to 24 months (

figure 2
).  Early signs include craniotabes (skull bones that depress with pressure), frontal bossing, and delayed fontanelle closure.  Bowing of the long bones is dependent on physiologic extremity alignment and the weight-bearing biomechanical forces at the time that the bone weakness develops, as follows (
figure 3
):



  • Age <1:  Bowing of the forearms and the distal tibia is more common in infants who crawl.
  • Age 1-2:  Exaggeration of the normal physiologic bowing of the legs (genu varum) can occur when a toddler first begins to walk.
  • Age 2-6:  An exaggerated knock-knee deformity may be present in a walking child whose lower extremities have undergone a physiologic transition to genu valgum.


Other physical examination findings include palpable nodules at the costochondral junction (rachitic rosary), widened wrists and knees due to growth plate enlargement, and kyphoscoliosis.  Hypotonia and gross motor delay can occur as a result of the altered skeletal structure.

Evaluation and diagnosis



Radiographs assessing the growth plates of rapidly growing bones can support a clinical diagnosis of rickets by demonstrating the following features:



  • Bowing of extremity long bones.
  • Widened growth plates and metaphyseal cupping/fraying at the wrists and knees (
    image 1
    ).
  • Enlarged costochondral joints (rachitic rosary) (
    image 2
    ).


Laboratory testing is required to determine the cause of rickets.  Vitamin D deficiency rickets is consistent with the following serum levels:



  • Low 25-hydroxyvitamin D (major circulatory form).
  • Low calcium (may be normal before advanced disease).
  • Low phosphate.
  • Elevated alkaline phosphatase.
  • Elevated parathyroid hormone.

Differential diagnosis



Vitamin D deficiency rickets should be differentiated from other conditions that cause skeletal abnormalities in young children.



  • Hypophosphatemic rickets:  This form of rickets typically occurs due to an inability of the kidneys to reabsorb phosphate, leading to both hypophospatemia and hypocalcemia, and subsequent bone deformities and short stature.  In contrast to hypocalcemic rickets, patients have a low/normal parathyroid hormone level.
  • Infantile Blount disease:  This occurs due to disruption of cartilage development at the proximal tibial growth plate and can result in bilateral, severe varus deformity.  It typically occurs in infants or toddlers who are obese and begin walking early.  Additional skeletal findings such as craniotabes or rachitic rosary are not present.
  • Achondroplasia (
    figure 4
    ):  In achondroplasia, decreased chondrocyte proliferation and hypertrophy during endochondral ossification can result in genu varum and frontal bossing.  Enlarged growth plates are not seen, and rhizomelia and midface hypoplasia are expected.
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta (
    figure 5
    ):  This is a congenital defect in the type I collagen structure that results in increased bone fragility.  Patients may have bowing deformities of long bones and frontal bossing.  However, craniotabes and rachitic rosary are not expected.  In addition, other features such as blue sclerae would also be present.
  • Congenital syphilis:  Congenital syphilis is often asymptomatic but may cause skeletal abnormalities, including craniotabes, frontal bossing, and anterior bowing of the shins.  Metaphyseal cupping and fraying and rachitic rosary are not seen.

Prevention and management



Vitamin D supplementation is recommended for exclusively breastfed infants to prevent rickets.  Infants who receive the majority of their nutrition from formula typically do not require additional supplementation because formula is often fortified with vitamin D.



In older children, dietary vitamin D is naturally found in organ meats (eg, liver), egg yolk, and oily fish (eg, salmon, sardines).  Some food products (eg, cow's milk, cereals) are fortified with vitamin D.  Adequate sun exposure provides an additional source for obtaining vitamin D.



Treatment for vitamin D deficiency rickets includes vitamin D and calcium supplementation.

Prognosis and complications



With early recognition and treatment, most skeletal deformities can resolve completely.  Untreated rickets may result in short stature, abnormal dentition, or permanent skeletal deformities.  Severe cases can have complications related to hypocalcemia (eg, tetany, paresthesia) and hypophosphatemia (eg, muscle weakness, altered mental status).

Summary



Vitamin D deficiency rickets (
